title: How to Uninstall Windows 7 from Your Computer

steps.title: Back up your files
steps.content: Back up your files . When replacing Windows 7 with a different operating system, you will lose some or all of your files. The best way to prevent permanent loss is by transferring all of the files that you want to keep to an external hard drive. Even though most modern operating systems give you the option of keeping your files when installing the operating system, backing up your files is a safety precaution that you shouldn't skip.

steps.title: Insert the installation disk or flash drive.
steps.content: Insert the installation disk or flash drive. To install a new operating system on Windows, you must have the operating system's install tool on a DVD or flash drive, and the disk or flash drive must be inserted into your computer. If you don't have a version of the operating system you want to download, you can download one for the following operating systems: Windows 10 Windows 8 Windows 7

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Click the Power button .
steps.content: Click the Power button . It's in the bottom-left corner of the Start window. A pop-up window will appear.

steps.title: Click Restart.
steps.content: Click Restart . You'll see this option at the top of the pop-up window. Clicking it will prompt your computer to restart.

steps.title: Press and hold Del or F2 to open the BIOS.
steps.content: Press and hold Del or F2 to open the BIOS. Most computers will display a message on startup that says "Press [key] to enter setup" or something similar. This key may vary, so look for this message when your computer restarts to confirm the key you should press to access the BIOS. Consult your computer's manual or online support page to confirm your computer's BIOS key.

steps.title: Select the Boot tab.
steps.content: Select the Boot tab. You'll use the arrow keys to select this tab. The Boot tab may instead say Boot Options , depending on your computer's manufacturer.

steps.title: Select a boot device.
steps.content: Select a boot device. Use the arrow keys to highlight a device from which to boot. There will be two options you can use: For a USB flash drive , select the Removable Devices option. For a disc installation , select the CD-ROM Drive option.

steps.title: Move your boot option to the top of the list.
steps.content: Move your boot option to the top of the list. Press the + key until your boot option is first. This will cause your computer to restart from your selected boot option, thereby beginning the installation process for your selected operating system. On some computers, you'll instead press one of the function keys (e.g., F5 ) to navigate an option up to the top of the menu. The key will be listed on the right side of the screen.

steps.title: Save your settings.
steps.content: Save your settings. You should see a key prompt (e.g., F10 ) at the bottom of the screen that has "Save and Exit" written next to it. Press this key to save and exit the BIOS. You may have to press ↵ Enter to confirm before you can exit the BIOS page.

steps.title: Wait for your computer to restart.
steps.content: Wait for your computer to restart. Once it does, you should see your chosen operating system's first setup window.

steps.title: Follow the on-screen installation directions.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen installation directions. Once you complete these, Windows 7 will be completely replaced by the new operating system. These directions will vary depending on the operating system you're installing: Windows 11 Windows 10 Windows 8

steps.title: Back up your files
steps.content: Back up your files . When you remove Windows 7, you will lose any files that aren't backed up. The easiest way to back up your Windows 7 files is by booting your computer into Windows 7, attaching an external hard drive, and transferring all of the files you want to keep onto the hard drive.

steps.title: Make sure you're using the operating system you want to keep.
steps.content: Make sure you're using the operating system you want to keep. You cannot delete Windows 7 while using it. If you aren't using a different operating system, restart your computer and then select the operating system you want to keep during the restart process.

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen. You can also press the ⊞ Win key on your keyboard. If you're on Windows 8, place the mouse cursor in the top- or bottom-right corner of the screen, then click the magnifying glass icon.

steps.title: Type system configuration into Start.
steps.content: Type system configuration into Start. This will search your computer for the System Configuration utility. On Windows 8, type into the search bar instead. System Configuration is available on most versions of Windows.

steps.title: Click System Configuration.
steps.content: Click System Configuration . It's either at the top of the Start window (Windows 10) or below the search bar (Windows 8). Doing so opens the System Configuration window.

steps.title: Click the Boot tab.
steps.content: Click the Boot tab. You'll see this at the top of the System Configuration window.

steps.title: Select your current operating system.
steps.content: Select your current operating system. Click the operating system (e.g., Windows 10 or Windows 8) that you want to set as the default. You can't delete an operating system if it's set as your default. If your current operating system is already the default, skip this step and the next one.

steps.title: Click Set as default.
steps.content: Click Set as default . This will change the default operating system from Windows 7 to your current operating system.

steps.title: Select Windows 7.
steps.content: Select Windows 7 . Click this operating system to do so.

steps.title: Click Delete.
steps.content: Click Delete . This button is below the window that shows the currently installed operating systems.

steps.title: Click Apply, then click OK.
steps.content: Click Apply , then click OK . These are both at the bottom of the window. Doing so will indicate that you want to delete Windows 7.

steps.title: Restart your computer
steps.content: Restart your computer . Once your computer finishes rebooting, Windows 7 should be gone. You won't be able to use the Windows 7 hard drive space until you remove the partition that Windows 7 was using.
